Description: 'Kohl' tube of palm-column form: the opaque lavender-blue shaft has a glossy surface, its lower half decorated with slender chevrons of white and yellow glass. The base is outlined with a heavy white thread. Eight white and yellow threads encircle the top of the shaft. The elements of the capital are outlined with yellow threads while a white thread encircles the opening. Assembled from two pieces through centre of body. A turquoise-blue glass applicator of conventional form not separately numbered accompanies this tube.
Curator's comments: Bibliography: Sale Catalogue, 'James Burton Jr. Collection', Sotheby and Son (London, 25-7 July 1836), lot 339. The applicator already accompanied the tube at this date. According to the entry, the tube still 'contains some of the original colour used for the eyes'. At the sale the vessel was purchased by Samuel Rogers; Sale Catalogue, Samuel Rogers Collection, Christie, London, 28 April – 10 May 1856, no. 24; A. Nesbitt, 'Catalogue of the Collection of Glass formed by Felix Slade' (1871), no. 14, pl. I, fog. 2; B. Nolte, ‘Die Glasgefässe in Alten Ägypten (Berlin 1968), 148, pl. XXXIV, 43 (see for further bibliography). Published: Egyptian Treasures (Shanghai 1999): 252-253 No 78 Published: Egyptian Treasures (Bowers Museum 2000): 194-195
Bibliographic references: Andrews 2000 / Egyptian Treasures from the British Museum (p.194-195)
Tait 1991 / Five Thousand Years of Glass (fig.30, pp.32-33)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2014 Oct 14 - London, BM, G2, 'Collecting the World'
